text: Küssnacht am Rigi (official name since 2004: Küssnacht) is a village, a municipality and a district in the canton of Schwyz in Switzerland. It is the capital and municipality of the district of Küssnacht. == History == Küssnacht was first mentioned in 830 as Cossiniacum, defining the estate of the Roman Lord Cossinius. In 1424, Küssnacht became a district of the Canton of Schwyz. According to the legend of Wilhelm Tell, the hero shot the Austrian bailiff Gessler at the Hohle Gasse near the Gesslerburg with his crossbow. On 29 August 1935, Queen Astrid of the Belgians was killed here in a road accident. A memorial chapel ("Königin-Astrid-Kapelle") was built at the accident scene. A well-known folklore event on December 5 each year is the Klausjagen. == Geography == It is at the northern shore of Lake Lucerne and at the southern shore of Lake Zug below mount Rigi (). === Villages === The municipality has three villages Küssnacht, Immensee, and Merlischachen, the hamlet Haltikon, the industrial area Fänn, and the alp Seeboden. == References == == Other websites == *Official webpage *Tourist webpage *Future plans of Küssnacht *Hohle Gasse *Klausjagen Category:Municipalities of Schwyz Category:Districts of Schwyz Category:Villages in Schwyz
title: Küssnacht
